utterances: A larger crowd than usual gathered on the shores of the Sayat River, north of Kabul one recent Friday.
They squatted on the riverbanks and perched on a busy bridge overlooking the water, all staring at the small motorboat which was weaving back and forth in the fast current.
Abdul Zapur(ph), one of the men on the bridge, sat dressed in robes and a turban, stroking his gray beard as he watched in disbelief.
Have you ever seen a boat here before?
(Through translator) I saw a boat when I was a kid, and since then I haven't seen a boat.
On the crowded riverbank below, scores of Afghans were lining up to pay the equivalent of 40 cents for a five-minute ride in the rapids.
(Soundbite of people yelling)
When a foreigner got on board, someone joked that he should pay $50 for his trip.
(Soundbite of people whooping)
About a half-dozen people sat in the simple, fiberglass dingy as it motored into the river.
One Afghan looked worried at first and confessed that he did not know how to swim.
But another bearded, balding man leapt to his feet and began clapping and yelling.
(Soundbite of man clapping and yelling)
Even a stern warning from the captain, who was trying to keep the small boat from capsizing, couldn't dampen 35-year-old Shewali Hakzar's(ph) childlike enthusiasm.
(Through translator) Great!
I'm really happy to be in a ship inside the river.
In Pakistan, I was in a boat, but in my country, I have never seen a boat.
This little boat is a big deal for a landlocked country that has been incredibly isolated by decades of war.
Mr.
BABAGU MANGAL(ph) (Boat Owner): (Through translator) This is the very first ship of mine, or the very first ship in Afghanistan, and I brought it.
The owner is Babagu Mangal, who just imported the boat from neighboring Iran for about $2,500.
(Through translator) I was jobless and I didn't have any business.
So when I saw the water is good and a lot of people come here on picnics, I decided to buy a ship.
And that could be a good business for me.
And now I bought the ship and my business is very good now.
This was the first day Mangal's boat ride was open for business.
But the boat's operator, Janagal Karimi, says it was not easy to convince people to give it a try.
Mr.
JANAGAL KARIMI (Boat Captain) (Through translator) Well, the first visit I brought it here, nobody dared to get in it because they didn't think I would be able to drive it, you know, in the river.
But by the end of the day, nearly everybody in the crowd on the riverbank said they had gone for a ride.
And how was it?
(Soundbite of people speaking foreign language)
These were clearly happy customers.
But the happiest one of all was probably Shawali Hakzar, the bearded man who nearly flipped the boat during his ride.
He was seen later in the day driving back to Kabul, dancing and singing with his friends on the back of a pickup truck.
Ivan Watson, NPR News.

I want you to elaborate on something you write about the Romantic era, which really is of the early 19th century.
And you write at one point: The Romantic era never really ended.

And later you say: Every time a singer-songwriter is praised for projecting autobiographical authenticity, every time a movie star expresses the desire for a project that is, quote, ""more personal,"" every time a flop is subsequently re-categorized as a before-its-time masterpiece, all these are reverberations of the bombshell of Romanticism.
And one of its pre-eminent delivery systems was Beethoven's Fifth.
Yeah, I think that the Romantic era is another thing that we just sort of take for granted, because they've kind of always been there for us.
But it's amazing how many of these ideas were new around the time that Beethoven was writing music.
The whole idea that music picks up where language leaves off, which is pretty much a cliche nowadays, that was a very specific Romantic idea and it's one that's lasted.

And also, the idea that the artist is somehow more privileged in accessing these things beyond language, in accessing the sublime, in accessing glimpses of the divine - however you want to characterize it.
And a lot of the ideas we use to talk about music are these Romantic ideas.

Here's one other story that Matthew Guerrieri writes about those first four notes.
In World War II, the anti-German resistance in occupied Belgium needed a simple graffiti symbol.
A Belgian came up with the letter V.
It stood equally for victoire, victory in French, and freiheit or freedom in Flemish.
And once that V idea got back to the BBC and they wanted to start using it in their overseas broadcasts.
It was at the BBC that they had the idea of combining it with the Morse code for V, which is of course three short and one long.
And somebody at the BBC realized that, well, that matches Beethoven's Fifth.
So they could start using that as a little tag to symbolize that this was going to be a pro-Ally, propaganda broadcast from the BBC.
This was signal tone, from 1940 at the BBC, played on a timpani.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
It was done by a very famous percussionist of the time named James Blades.
When he recorded it, he later wrote that he had imagined it being the same thing as Drake's drum, which is this mythical drum in British history from Sir Francis Drake.
And the legend is that it will sound at times of national crisis in the hearts, and perhaps the ears, of patriotic Englishmen.
Well, Matthew Guerrieri, thank you very much for talking with us.
